utterances: Well, I just think that we're at a point of time in our political history where we don't trust each other at all, and the system that was put in place by our Founding Fathers was one where the secret ballot was sacred and gave us an opportunity to really voice our true opinion.

This is still a human being.
We're going to have to still stay engaged because the government's supposed to represent us, not do things for us.

Well, that's always the argument that is made against Election Day registration.
But if you look at the evidence, it's not founded.

First of all, Election Day registration, which nine states now have, can result and does result in a significant increase in participation, somewhere on the order of five to 10 percent, and that's huge in the area of voting.

Now in terms of the fraud concern, that's the argument that's always made, but if you look at states that have had Election Day registration, and three of them have been studied extensively because they've had it for over 30 years, you don't find evidence of increased fraud.
And the reason for that is it's very difficult to register in multiple places and produce the identification that you have to do to register on Election Day and not get caught.
And if you do get caught, you're at risk of being prosecuted for a felony.
So there's no evidence that fraud is more common in Election Day registration states than in other states.

There's a lot of talk out there about voter fraud and a lot of anecdotes out there, but if you actually look at the evidence, voter fraud is extremely rare.
And the best check that can be done is just to have a signature match.
